title: Saddle-to-Saddle Dynamics Explains A Simplicity Bias Across Neural Network Architectures
summary: This paper introduces a unifying theoretical framework, based on 'saddle-to-saddle dynamics,' to explain the widely observed phenomenon of 'simplicity bias' in neural networks, where models trained with gradient descent learn increasingly complex solutions over time. It demonstrates how this dynamic leads to an incremental increase in complexity metrics like rank, kinks, convolutional kernels, or attention heads across diverse architectures, including linear, ReLU, convolutional, and attention networks. The research also elucidates how data distribution and weight initialization influence the learning process, specifically affecting the duration and number of learning plateaus.
domains: Computational diagnostics (e.g., medical image analysis, pathology)

title: Automated stereotactic radiosurgery planning using a human-in-the-loop reasoning large language model agent
summary: This paper introduces SAGE (Secure Agent for Generative Dose Expertise), a large language model (LLM) agent designed for automated stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) planning, focusing on improving transparency through chain-of-thought reasoning. The reasoning variant of SAGE produced plan dosimetry comparable to human experts, significantly reduced cochlear dose, and generated auditable planning logs demonstrating systematic deliberative processes, addressing key barriers to AI adoption in radiation oncology.

title: Behavioral patterns and mean-field games in epidemiological models
summary: This paper introduces a novel Mean Field Game (MFG) epidemiological model that incorporates subpopulations with diverse behavioral patterns, including highly rational agents and those following pre-specified non-rational patterns. It demonstrates, using a Susceptible-Infected-Recovered-Susceptible-Dead (SIRSD) model, that the presence of non-rational behaviors and the allowance for behavioral switching significantly amplify the impact of infectious diseases. The research aims to bridge distinct modeling communities and promote behavioral considerations in broader MFG literature.

title: ScoreMatchingRiesz: Auto-DML with Infinitesimal Classification
summary: This study proposes ScoreMatchingRiesz, a novel method for Riesz representer estimation based on score matching, extending techniques from direct density ratio estimation (DRE) and diffusion models. The primary goal is to address the issue of overfitting commonly encountered with flexible models in Riesz representer estimation, which is crucial for constructing $\sqrt{n}$-consistent and efficient estimators in debiased machine learning (DML) for causal inference and structural parameter estimation. The proposed method not only mitigates overfitting but also offers new insights into causal inference by bridging marginal effects and average policy effects through time score functions.

title: Benchmarking LLMs for Predictive Applications in the Intensive Care Units
summary: This study benchmarks the performance of Large Language Models (LLMs) like GatorTron-Base, Llama 8B, and Mistral 7B against Smaller Language Models (SLMs) such as BioBERT and Word2Vec for predicting shock in critically ill ICU patients using text data from the MIMIC III database. The findings indicate that while GatorTron-Base achieved the highest weighted recall, the overall predictive performance metrics were comparable between LLMs and SLMs, suggesting that LLMs are not inherently superior for predicting future clinical events in this context.

title: Dual-Encoder Transformer-Based Multimodal Learning for Ischemic Stroke Lesion Segmentation Using Diffusion MRI
summary: This paper investigates automated ischemic stroke lesion segmentation from multimodal diffusion MRI (DWI and ADC) using various deep learning architectures. It proposes a dual-encoder TransUNet architecture that integrates adjacent slice information to achieve superior performance, reaching a Dice Similarity Coefficient of 85.4% on the test set.

title: Skin Lesion Classification Using a Soft Voting Ensemble of Convolutional Neural Networks
summary: This paper presents a novel method for early skin cancer classification using a soft voting ensemble of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). The approach incorporates comprehensive image preprocessing, transfer learning for accurate lesion segmentation, and an ensemble of MobileNetV2, VGG19, and InceptionV3 for classification, achieving high recognition accuracies across three benchmark dermoscopic datasets.

title: Chain-of-Anomaly Thoughts with Large Vision-Language Models
summary: This paper introduces Chain-of-Anomaly-Thoughts (CoAT), a multi-agent reasoning framework that enhances anomaly detection in automated video surveillance by mitigating Large Vision-Language Models' (LVLMs) inherent bias towards normality. CoAT incorporates an inductive criminal bias and an anomaly-focused classification layer, significantly boosting F1-score for Anomaly Detection by 11.8 percentage points in low-resolution footage and Anomaly Classification by 3.78 percentage points in high-resolution videos.

title: AUDRON: A Deep Learning Framework with Fused Acoustic Signatures for Drone Type Recognition
summary: AUDRON is a novel hybrid deep learning framework designed for robust drone type recognition using fused acoustic signatures. It leverages Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCC), Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT) spectrograms, and autoencoder representations, processed by convolutional and recurrent neural networks. The system achieves high accuracy of 98.51% for binary and 97.11% for multiclass classification, effectively distinguishing drones from background noise.

title: CLIP Based Region-Aware Feature Fusion for Automated BBPS Scoring in Colonoscopy Images
summary: This paper addresses the subjectivity and inter-observer variability of manual Boston Bowel Preparation Scale (BBPS) scoring in colonoscopy by proposing a novel automated framework. Leveraging a newly constructed high-quality dataset, their method integrates the CLIP model with adapter-based transfer learning and a fecal-feature extraction branch, fusing global visual features with stool-related textual priors. This approach significantly improves the accuracy of bowel cleanliness evaluation without requiring explicit segmentation, demonstrating superior performance over existing baselines.

title: Multi-LLM Thematic Analysis with Dual Reliability Metrics: Combining Cohen's Kappa and Semantic Similarity for Qualitative Research Validation
summary: Qualitative research faces a critical reliability challenge: traditional inter-rater agreement methods require multiple human coders, are time-intensive, and often yield moderate consistency.
